I think they said they were like three and a half inches. And they go into the epidural space. They put in a contrast. That's what makes the nerves here. You can actually see the nerves. It's what makes the nerves this darker color so that they can see them. And then, yeah, interesting. I thought overall. So fun stuff all around. All right. Now let's

This is actually exactly where those short calls are useful. Now the downside to the short calls is that if we get a big spike, they get ran over and it can offer a massive problem. That's why I always, always sell them at a ratio. So what I mean by that is I'm going to make sure I have at least more than 100 shares of game stop if I'm going to sell one call so that if my shares get called away for whatever reason, unlikely, but if they did in that big up move, I have the shares to offer because I do not want to be short game stop. That's a terrible place to be. And that's not just because of the fun of talking about how screwed up the shorts are, but from a trader's perspective, that can put you in a really bad spot if there is a squeeze. Unfortunately, at that same point in time. So by keeping it at a ratio, I make sure I do not cap my profit potential if there is a squeeze because I do not want to cap the profit potential during those movements. I want to be able to trade them. That's what I do. So a couple other admin

text: we'll size this up so that it mirrors what we have. So we'll analyze this. We'll add this up so that it's 550 of those. And then we got those again for maybe like five. We'll call it like 540 or something like that. So that's the trade. And if you're wondering what that trade is, it essentially is just looking for movement. Now, this can happen in a few different ways. But this is more likely a play on volatility than anything else. That's what I see here. Because by coming into this really near term position, I'm seeing the idea that we're playing probably close, vol expanding is what I'm guessing. But again, the most important point to note here is we don't know what else is in this person's book, right? And that's what makes it such a sloppy game of trying to understand what they're doing. Because I have no idea what else is in this person's portfolio. And even though these trades went on seemingly at the same time and seemingly make this, it doesn't necessarily tell us the whole picture of what else is held in the portfolio and how maybe these don't even line up with one another. Maybe they were just put on at the same time, but tied to other positions. Really hard to say. But if I were to look at these in a vacuum to interpulse question, it looks like a volatility play. That's my best guess. So got
